ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: An overall comprehension of concepts of faking and forgery in ancient texts.

The course focused on ideas of authenticity, forgery and attribution as well larger issues of canonicity and the transmission of antiquities. The class asked us to challenge conventional ideas around these discourses.

I think that this class was somewhat helpful for developing different ways of thinking about the issue of forgery. I was particularly interested in the concept of literary forgery. Unfortunately, I think that the content was in some ways too diverse though, and as a result became spread a bit thin. There was a lot of catch up work to get people to baseline understanding for much of the Assyrian (for example) material. I think that there were also too many case-study readings for class (especially since we ended up focusing on one). It would have been helpful, I think, to explore a single case study deeply for several classes.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The structure of this course made very little sense
I think there were ongoing technological problems with the projector. I think it also would have helped to allow grad students to speak more in class and challenge each other.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No. I did not like this class.
Yes, I think this interdisciplinary forum is important and the focus on textual and material philologies provided a unique class.

I think that if this course were to change in its focus to hone in on fewer issues it would be more effective and would recommend this course to someone who was interested in the issue of fakes and forgeries.
